title: Estimate activity centers from acoustic telemetry data
text: vignette walk analyses presented Winton et al. 2018, describe use spatial point process models estimate individual centers activity passive acoustic telemetry data. vignette progresses applying simplest case, assumes detection probabilities/receiver detection ranges remain constant time, application test-tag integrated model, incorporates detection data one stationary test transmitters estimate time-varying detection ranges. models fitted Bayesian framework using Stan software (Carpenter et al. 2017); code modified provided Royle et al. 2013 fitting spatial point process models data camera traps. prefer Bayesian approach COA estimation due treatment uncertainty, realize longer computational time required may prohibitive applications. near future, update include option fit maximum likelihood framework, reduce run times. ’d also like note models described can support varying degrees complexity - applications require (data support) complex version model. simpler model, shorter run-time. realize many users unique situations may need modify base code suit purposes. Users can copy .stan files contained src/stan_files folder local machine . happy accommodate user requests (schedules allow). hope make collaborative package evolve based needs acoustic telemetry community continue improve time. tried make instructions outlined vignette user-friendly since group applied biologists varying degrees statistical experience. statistical notation outlined paper remains unclear, feel free contact us questions/clarification. actually intuitive, like make sure comes documentation. new package, find bugs, places code efficiency improved, instances documentation made user-friendly, please let us know!

title: Estimate activity centers from acoustic telemetry data
text: package includes two data sets: 153 hours detection data black sea bass (note assigned time number cumulative hours since tag deployed rather providing raw date/time stamp), hourly detections stationary test transmitter time period. Two files containing receiver coordinates location test tag also included. provided data format illustrate data preparation specific fitting types models; however, need aggregate date/time stamps time period interest. Receiver test tag coordinates provided Universal Transverse Mercator (zone 18) projection, previously mean-centered scaled kilometers. scaling step highly recommended reduce run-times. words, dataset prior starting code chunks . access provided data, run: Prior anything else, need specify ‘state space’ - spatial extent interest. consist receiver array ‘buffer’ area around array. buffer needs large enough allow individuals may activity centers outside receiver array. general rule thumb , scale geographic extent covered array. suggest selecting buffer large enough allow discriminate individuals detected along periphery array individuals detected - COA estimated time steps unless specify individual left area; time steps 0 detections estimated COA somewhere outside detection range receivers (note within array bounds array non-continuous coverage). many time steps zeros, may want modify data file omit time periods 0 detections modify relevant .stan code chunk included src/stan_files folder local machine skip time periods detections, speed computing times. always, user make sure results make sense context species/array interest. Next, need prepare test tag data. First, calculate distance test tag’s location receiver. can done using included ‘distf’ function. Tally many time intervals receiver operational - allows individual receivers deployed different periods /receivers lost. Since detection records include non-zero events (assuming ’d like keep time steps zeros), ’ll need convert number detections include zeros receivers detect tag time period. Now ’ll thing black sea bass detection data.
code: library(TelemetrySpace) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2) library(hexbin) library(ggpubr)  rlocs # Receiver locations ## # A tibble: 30 × 3 ##    Station   east  north ##    <chr>    <dbl>  <dbl> ##  1 SB1     -1.33  1.61   ##  2 SB2     -0.579 1.91   ##  3 SB3      0.219 2.00   ##  4 SB4      1.00  1.81   ##  5 SB5     -1.69  0.896  ##  6 SB6     -0.879 0.950  ##  7 SB7     -0.231 1.20   ##  8 SB8      0.464 1.21   ##  9 SB9      1.28  1.04   ## 10 SB10    -1.77  0.0952 ## # ℹ 20 more rows testloc # Test tag location ## # A tibble: 1 × 2 ##     east north ##    <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 -0.329 0.713 head(testdat) # Hourly detection data from the test tag ## # A tibble: 6 × 5 ##   Station Transmitter   east north  hour ##   <chr>         <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 SB12           3447 -0.326 0.513     1 ## 2 SB13           3447  0.125 0.575     1 ## 3 SB7            3447 -0.231 1.20      1 ## 4 SB6            3447 -0.879 0.950     1 ## 5 SB13           3447  0.125 0.575     1 ## 6 SB6            3447 -0.879 0.950     1 head(fishdat) # Hourly detection data from a black sea bass ## # A tibble: 6 × 5 ##   Station Transmitter   east north  hour ##   <chr>         <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 SB15           3425  0.190 0.209     1 ## 2 SB14           3425 -0.261 0.159     1 ## 3 SB15           3425  0.190 0.209     1 ## 4 SB14           3425 -0.261 0.159     1 ## 5 SB12           3425 -0.326 0.513     1 ## 6 SB14           3425 -0.261 0.159     1 # Define state-space of point process - 'buffer' adds a fixed buffer to the outer extent of the recs buffer <- 1 xlim <- c(min(rlocs$east - buffer), max(rlocs$east + buffer)) ylim <- c(min(rlocs$north - buffer), max(rlocs$north + buffer)) # Set up a blank vector for storage D <- NULL # Loop over each hour for(i in 1:nrow(testdat)){   D[i] <- distf(testloc[, c('east', 'north')], testdat[i, c('east', 'north')]) }  testdat$D <- unlist(D) # Assign to testdat data frame  # Plot to examine variation in detection rate over time testdat |>    count(Station, hour, D, east, north) |>    mutate(     dist = round(D * 1000), #Round distance for plotting     label = paste(dist, "m", "(", Station, ")") #Create label by merging station name and distance   ) |>    #Plot using ggplot   ggplot(aes(x = hour, y = n)) +     geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = '#008080') +     facet_wrap(~ as.factor(label)) +     theme(text = element_text(size = 16)) +     scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0,30,10)) +     labs(x = "Hours since deployment",y = "Number of detections") # The full analysis takes several hours to run, so we'll subset out 10 hours to illustrate fishdat <- fishdat |>    filter(hour < 11) testdat <- testdat |>    filter(hour < 11)  # Create a copy of the receiver locations for tallying rs <- rlocs  # Add column for each time interval to indicate whether receiver was operational or not rs[, c(4:(max(fishdat$hour) + 3))] <- 1  # Create vector of the number of sampling occasions for each receiver  tsteps <- rowSums(rs[, 4:ncol(rs)]) tsteps # Will all be the same here because all operational over the entire time span ##  [1] 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 10 ## [26] 10 10 10 10 10 ## Starting with the test tag data test_agg <- testdat |>    mutate(     rec = as.numeric(substr(Station, 3, 4)),     # Add a column that indicates each record corresponds to 1 detection     count = 1   ) |>     # Aggregate the number of detections for each individual at each receiver   # in each time step   count(Transmitter, rec, east, north, hour) |>     # Create a numeric identifier for each transmitter   mutate(tag = as.numeric(as.factor(Transmitter))) |>     # Rename hour to time for consistency when plotting below   rename(time = "hour")  # Specify quantities for indexing #   number of individual tags (here just the one test tag) ntest <- length(unique(test_agg$Transmitter))  #   number of receivers nrec <- nrow(rlocs)  #   number of time steps tsteps <- max(test_agg$time)  # This chunk saves the total number of encounters of each individual (rows) in  #each trap (cols) at each sampling occasion (array elements) testY <- array(NA, dim=c(ntest, nrec, tsteps))  for(t in 1:tsteps){   for (i in 1:ntest){     h1 <- test_agg[test_agg$tag == i,]      for(j in 1:nrec){       testY[i, j, t] <- ifelse(          # If there are no detections at that receiver in that time period, set to 0         nrow(h1[h1$time == t & h1$rec == j,]) == 0,         0,          # otherwise set to the number of detections         h1[h1$time == t & h1$rec == j,]$n       )     }   }   } ## Now do the same for each tagged fish fish_agg <- fishdat |>    mutate(     rec = as.numeric(substr(Station, 3, 4)),     # Add a column that indicates each record corresponds to 1 detection     count = 1   ) |>     # Aggregate the number of detections for each individual at each receiver   # in each time step   count(Transmitter, rec, east, north, hour) |>     # Create a numeric identifier for each transmitter   mutate(tag = as.numeric(as.factor(Transmitter))) |>     # Rename hour to time for consistency when plotting below   rename(time = "hour")  # Specify quantities for indexing #   number of individual tags (here just the one test tag) nind <- length(unique(fish_agg$Transmitter))  # This chunk saves the total number of encounters of each individual (rows) in each trap (cols) at each sampling occasion (array elements) Y <- array(NA, dim=c(nind, nrec, tsteps))  for(t in 1:max(tsteps)){   for (i in 1:nrow(Y)){      h1 <- fish_agg[fish_agg$tag == i,]      for(j in 1:nrow(rlocs)){       # If there are no detections at that receiver in that time period, set to 0; otherwise set to the number of detections       Y[i, j, t] <- ifelse(          # If there are no detections at that receiver in that time period, set to 0         nrow(h1[h1$time == t & h1$rec == j,]) == 0,         0,          # otherwise set to the number of detections         h1[h1$time == t & h1$rec == j,]$n       )     }   } }

title: Estimate activity centers from acoustic telemetry data
text: data processing, ’re finally ready fit model! ’ll start fitting model assuming detection probabilities among receivers remain constant time (know, pretty much never case ‘real-life’ best start simple). Besides, model handy don’t test-tag () data available inform detection probabilities like able estimate COAs along periphery array. information ’ll need provide expected number transmissions per tag per time interval (ntrans ). function automatically spit run-time associated 4 chains used fitting returns list four objects: first contains Stan model object (accessible via fit$Model, allow use rstan plotting tools diagnostic plots - see rstan documentation details). second element table parameter estimates associated quantiles posterior distribution. table also includes effective sample size Rhat statistic (~1). third returns time required run model (minutes). Note Stan automatically detect use multiple cores. computer used run multiple cores, time returned longer actual run time (sum time core). return realized run time, divide fit$Time number cores. fourth returns array COA estimates, matrix corresponds one individual, rows correspond time step, columns include median posterior estimate east-west (x) north-south (y) coordinates. 95% credible interval (Bayesian version confidence interval) coordinate also provided. last element (fit$All_estimates) contains estimates non-warm-iteration 4 chains. (’re familiar Bayesian lingo just seems like statistical jargon, need know ’ll use plot uncertainty cloud around COA estimates /distribution parameter estimates presented paper.) includes estimates latent parameters individual time step (aka element contains tons parameter estimates), need subset parameters plotting.
code: ### Format data for model fitting fit <- COA_Standard(   nind = nind,    # number of individuals   nrec = nrec,    # number of receivers   ntime = tsteps, # number of time steps   ntrans = 30,    # number of expected transmissions per tag per time interval   y = Y,          # array of detections   recX = as.vector(rlocs$east),  # E-W receiver coordinates   recY = as.vector(rlocs$north), # N-S receiver coordinates   xlim = xlim, # E-W boundary of spatial extent (receiver array + buffer)   ylim = ylim  # N-S boundary of spatial extent (receiver array + buffer) ) ##         warmup sample ## chain:1  2.298  1.985 ## chain:2  1.830  2.315 ## chain:3  1.749  1.337 ## chain:4  1.759  2.078 summary(fit) ##               Length Class      Mode    ## model           1    stanfit    S4      ## summary        20    -none-     numeric ## time            1    -none-     numeric ## coas            7    data.frame list    ## all_estimates 325    data.frame list fit$summary ##            mean      se_mean         sd      2.5%       25%       50%       75% ## p0    0.2822800 0.0004478783 0.02520083 0.2361652 0.2644027 0.2813702 0.2994305 ## sigma 0.2845763 0.0002817552 0.01493595 0.2554774 0.2742519 0.2845919 0.2947178 ##           97.5%    n_eff     Rhat ## p0    0.3329404 3165.990 1.000794 ## sigma 0.3141591 2810.101 1.001010 fit$time ## [1] 0.25585 fit$coas ##    time           x         y    x_lower     x_upper    y_lower   y_upper ## 1     1 -0.04419208 0.2936790 -0.1462210  0.05951826 0.18845035 0.4023171 ## 2     2 -0.02330482 0.3578317 -0.1420680  0.09773196 0.21932718 0.5005321 ## 3     3 -0.09875625 0.3839595 -0.2569494  0.04730306 0.19878372 0.5686053 ## 4     4 -0.12329253 0.2816735 -0.2786449  0.02481079 0.10911757 0.4669253 ## 5     5 -0.16831392 0.3242430 -0.3259290 -0.02445424 0.15206068 0.5067735 ## 6     6 -0.13019674 0.7062093 -0.4725975  0.17890991 0.17035957 0.8814318 ## 7     7 -0.05163113 0.3667484 -0.1700821  0.07165783 0.23090152 0.4937734 ## 8     8 -0.15522780 0.4049252 -0.2793242 -0.03514842 0.27458678 0.5346351 ## 9     9 -0.05002765 0.3329523 -0.2220192  0.11698386 0.12850061 0.5501859 ## 10   10 -0.09807742 0.3133353 -0.2885934  0.07443582 0.08394051 0.5651978 # Extract east-west and north-south coordinates of COAs from each iteration of each chain # Note that 'sx' and 'sy' are the variable names used to store the coordinates for each individual (rows) in each time step (columns). # We'll store them as a list, where each element corresponds to an individual EN_fit <- list(NA)  for (i in 1:nind){   EN_fit[[i]] <- bind_cols(     # East-West     fit$all_estimates |>        select(starts_with(paste("sx[", i, ",", sep=''))) |>        pivot_longer(everything(), values_to = "X"),     # North-South     fit$all_estimates |>        select(starts_with(paste("sy[", i, ",", sep=''))) |>        pivot_longer(everything(), values_to = "Y") |>        select(Y)   ) |>    # The ID field corresponds to the time step.   mutate(time = as.numeric(gsub(".*,|\\]", "", name))) }  ## Plot posterior estimates # Select individual for plotting post_fit <- EN_fit[[1]] coa_fit <- as.data.frame(fit$coas[, , 1])  # Plot in ggplot plotCOAs <- ggplot(aes(x = X, y = Y), data = post_fit) +   geom_hex(alpha = 1, bins = 100)  +   geom_point(aes(x = x, y = y), data = coa_fit, pch = 25, cex = 1.5, alpha = .8, fill = NA) +   facet_wrap(~ time, ncol = 2) +   scale_fill_gradientn(colours = c("white", "blue"), name = "Frequency", na.value = NA) +   geom_point(aes(x = east, y = north), data = rlocs, cex = 1) +   geom_point(aes(x = east, y = north), data = fish_agg, pch = 21, cex = 1.5, fill = '#00BFC4') +      # Unhash line below to include test tag location   #geom_point(aes(x = east, y = north), data = testloc, cex = 1.5, pch = 21, fill = '#F8766D') +      coord_fixed(xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-0.5, 1.5)) +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(-1, 0, 1)) +   #scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(-1, 0, 1)) +   theme(legend.position = "none") +   labs(x = 'East-West (km)', y = 'North-South (km)')

what: Fit a COA model that allows for receiver- and time-specific detection probabilities
title: Estimate activity centers from acoustic telemetry data
text: Now let’s fit model allows variation detection probabilities. model simple extension previous model - just allows detection probability vary time steps receivers. information ’ll need provide expected number transmissions per tag per time interval (ntrans).
code: ### Format data for model fitting fit_vary <- COA_TimeVarying(   nind = nind,    # number of individuals   nrec = nrec,    # number of receivers   ntime = tsteps, # number of time steps   ntrans = 30,    # number of expected transmissions per tag per time interval   y = Y,          # array of detections from tagged fish   recX = as.vector(rlocs$east),  # E-W receiver coordinates   recY = as.vector(rlocs$north), # N-S receiver coordinates   xlim = xlim, # E-W boundary of spatial extent (receiver array + buffer)   ylim = ylim  # N-S boundary of spatial extent (receiver array + buffer) ) ##         warmup sample ## chain:1 24.266 14.747 ## chain:2 22.624 17.264 ## chain:3 23.072 14.642 ## chain:4 22.762 14.569 summary(fit_vary) ##                 Length Class      Mode    ## model              1   stanfit    S4      ## summary         3010   -none-     numeric ## time               1   -none-     numeric ## coas               7   data.frame list    ## detection_probs  300   -none-     numeric ## all_estimates    923   data.frame list fit_vary$time ## [1] 2.565767 # As before, extract east-west and north-south coordinates of COAs from each iteration of each chain # Note that 'sx' and 'sy' are the variable names used to store the coordinates for each individual (rows) in each time step (columns). # We'll store them as a list, where each element corresponds to an individual EN_vary <- list(NA)  for (i in 1:nind){   EN_vary[[i]] <- bind_cols(     # East-West     fit_vary$all_estimates |>        select(starts_with(paste("sx[", i, ",", sep=''))) |>        pivot_longer(everything(), values_to = "X"),     # North-South     fit_vary$all_estimates |>        select(starts_with(paste("sy[", i, ",", sep=''))) |>        pivot_longer(everything(), values_to = "Y") |>        select(Y)   ) |>    # The ID field corresponds to the time step.   mutate(time = as.numeric(gsub(".*,|\\]", "", name))) }  ## Plot posterior estimates # Select individual for plotting post_vary <- EN_vary[[1]] coa_vary <- as.data.frame(fit_vary$coas[, , 1])  # Plot in ggplot plotTVary <- ggplot(aes(x = X, y = Y), data = post_vary) +     geom_hex(alpha = 1, bins = 100)  +     geom_point(aes(x = x, y = y), data = coa_vary,       pch = 25, cex = 1.5, alpha = .8, fill = NA     ) +     facet_wrap(~time, ncol = 2) +     scale_fill_gradientn(colours=  c("white", "blue"), name = "Frequency", na.value=NA) +     geom_point(aes(x = east, y = north), data = rlocs, cex = 1) +     geom_point(aes(x = east,y = north), data = fish_agg, pch = 21, cex = 1.5, fill = '#00BFC4') +          # Unhash line below to include test tag location       #geom_point(aes(x=east,y=north),data=testloc,cex=1.5,pch=21,fill='#F8766D') +          coord_fixed(xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-0.5, 1.5)) +     scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(-1, 0, 1)) +     #scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(-1, 0, 1)) +     theme(legend.position = "none") +     labs(x = 'East-West (km)', y = 'North-South (km)')

what: Fit a model that uses detections from a moored test tag to inform detection probabilities
title: Estimate activity centers from acoustic telemetry data
text: Now ’ll fit exciting model - model integrates test tag data inform detection probabilities. model simple extension previous models - just adds component specifies distance test tag receiver, shifts probability detection comparing number detections logged receiver versus emitted test tag time step. words, treats test tags tagged individuals known COAs. information ’ll need provide expected number transmissions per tag per time interval (ntrans).
code: ### Format data for model fitting ## Specify the number of sentinel tags (this step is necessary because of issues that arise with Stan indexing if you have only 1 test tag) nsentinel <- 1  fit_tag <- COA_TagInt(   nind = nind,       # number of individuals   nrec = nrec,       # number of receivers   ntime = tsteps,    # number of time steps   ntest = nsentinel, # number of test tags   ntrans = 30,       # number of expected transmissions per tag per time interval   y = Y,             # array of detections from tagged fish   test = testY,      # array of detections from test tags   recX = as.vector(rlocs$east),  # E-W receiver coordinates   recY = as.vector(rlocs$north), # N-S receiver coordinates    xlim = xlim, # E-W boundary of spatial extent (receiver array + buffer)   ylim = ylim, # N-S boundary of spatial extent (receiver array + buffer)   testX = array(testloc$east, dim = c(nsentinel)),   testY = array(testloc$north, dim = c(nsentinel)) ) ##         warmup sample ## chain:1 19.695 10.553 ## chain:2 18.609 10.535 ## chain:3 19.143 10.438 ## chain:4 20.521  9.958 summary(fit_tag) ##                 Length Class      Mode    ## model              1   stanfit    S4      ## summary         3010   -none-     numeric ## time               1   -none-     numeric ## coas               7   data.frame list    ## detection_probs  300   -none-     numeric ## all_estimates    953   data.frame list fit_tag$time # See the comment about run time when your computer has multiple cores above. ## [1] 1.990867 # As before, extract east-west and north-south coordinates of COAs from each iteration of each chain # Note that 'sx' and 'sy' are the variable names used to store the coordinates for each individual (rows) in each time step (columns). # We'll store them as a list, where each element corresponds to an individual EN_tag <- list(NA)  for (i in 1:nind){   EN_tag[[i]] <- bind_cols(     # East-West     fit_tag$all_estimates |>        select(starts_with(paste("sx[", i, ",", sep=''))) |>        pivot_longer(everything(), values_to = "X"),     # North-South     fit_tag$all_estimates |>        select(starts_with(paste("sy[", i, ",", sep=''))) |>        pivot_longer(everything(), values_to = "Y") |>        select(Y)   ) |>    # The ID field corresponds to the time step.   mutate(time = as.numeric(gsub(".*,|\\]", "", name))) }  ## Plot posterior estimates # Select individual for plotting post_tag <- EN_tag[[1]] coa_tag <- as.data.frame(fit_tag$coas[, , 1])  # Plot in ggplot plotTagInt <- ggplot(aes(x = X, y = Y), data = post_tag) +   geom_hex(alpha = 1, bins = 100)  +   geom_point(aes(x = x, y = y),     data = coa_tag, pch = 25, cex = 1.5, alpha = 0.8, fill = NA   ) +   facet_wrap(~time, ncol = 2) +   scale_fill_gradientn(colours = c("white", "blue"), name = "Frequency", na.value = NA) +   geom_point(aes(x = east, y = north), data = rlocs, cex = 1) +   geom_point(aes(x = east, y = north), data = fish_agg, pch = 21, cex = 1.5, fill = '#00BFC4') +    # Unhash line below to plot test tag location   #geom_point(aes(x=east,y=north),data=testloc,cex=1.5,pch=21,fill='#F8766D') +    coord_fixed(xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-0.5, 1.5)) +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(-1, 0, 1)) +   theme(legend.position = "none") +   labs(x = 'East-West (km)', y = 'North-South (km)')

title: Estimate activity centers from acoustic telemetry data
text: Now plot together see compare!
code: ggarrange(plotCOAs, plotTVary, plotTagInt,           labels = c("Standard", "Time-varying", "Tag-integrated"),           ncol = 3, nrow = 1,           align = "hv",           #widths = c(8,8,8), heights = c(2,2,2),           common.legend = F)

title: Estimate activity centers from acoustic telemetry data
text: Carpenter, B., Gelman, ., Hoffman, M. D., Lee, D., Goodrich, B., Betancourt, M., … & Riddell, . (2017). Stan: probabilistic programming language. Journal statistical software, 76, 1-32. Royle, J. ., Chandler, R. B., Sollmann, R., & Gardner, B. (2013). Spatial capture-recapture. Academic press. Winton, M. V., Kneebone, J., Zemeckis, D. R., & Fay, G. (2018). spatial point process model estimate individual centres activity passive acoustic telemetry data. Methods Ecology Evolution, 9(11), 2262-2272.

what: Spatial point process and random field models for electronic tagging data
title: Spatial point process and random field models for electronic tagging data
text: [!CAUTION] August 2025, development TelemetrySpace moved https://github.com/trackyverse/TelemetrySpace. Please direct new issues pull requests repository. TelemetrySpace package implements model described Winton et al. 2018, spatial point process model estimate individual centres activity passive acoustic telemetry data.

title: Spatial point process and random field models for electronic tagging data
text: suggest installing via Ocean Tracking Network’s R-universe: TelemetrySpace package uses Stan model fitting. like use ---date versions Stan RStan dependencies, please follow instructions https://github.com/stan-dev/rstan/wiki/RStan-Getting-Started.
code: install.packages('TelemetrySpace', repos = c('https://ocean-tracking-network.r-universe.dev', getOption("repos"))

title: Spatial point process and random field models for electronic tagging data
text: also offer Docker image dependencies pre-installed. use Docker image, first install Docker. , can run R session TelemetrySpace installed running following command terminal: bring data Docker container, can mount local directory Docker container using -v flag. example, mount ~/data directory /data Docker container, can run:
code: docker pull ghcr.io/trackyverse/telemetryspace:latest docker run --rm -it \   -p 8888:8888 \   ghcr.io/trackyverse/telemetryspace:latest docker run --rm -it \   -p 8888:8888 \   -v $PWD/data:/data \   ghcr.io/trackyverse/telemetryspace:latest

what: Fits a Bayesian Spatial Point Process model to estimate individual centers of activity from acoustic telemetry data using Stan — COA_Standard
title: Fits a Bayesian Spatial Point Process model to estimate individual centers of activity from acoustic telemetry data using Stan — COA_Standard
text: Fits Bayesian Spatial Point Process model estimate individual centers activity acoustic telemetry data using Stan

title: Fits a Bayesian Spatial Point Process model to estimate individual centers of activity from acoustic telemetry data using Stan — COA_Standard
code: COA_Standard(nind, nrec, ntime, ntrans, y, recX, recY, xlim, ylim, ...)

title: Fits a Bayesian Spatial Point Process model to estimate individual centers of activity from acoustic telemetry data using Stan — COA_Standard
text: nind Number tagged individuals nrec Number receivers ntime Number time steps ntrans Number expected transmissions per tag per time interval y Array detection data, row = individual, column = receiver, matrix = time step recX Receiver coordinates east-west direction (projected scaled computational efficiency) recY Receiver coordinates north-south direction (projected scaled computational efficiency) xlim East-west boundaries spatial extent (receiver array + buffer) ylim North-south boundaries spatial extent (receiver array + buffer) ... Additional arguments passed sampling rstan. can include setting chains, iter, warmup, control. Please see rstan::sampling info.

title: Fits a Bayesian Spatial Point Process model to estimate individual centers of activity from acoustic telemetry data using Stan — COA_Standard
text: COA_Standard returns object class stanfit returned rstan::sampling. See rstan package documentation details. function returns list containing following components: 1) summary detection function parameters; 2) time required model fitting; 3) estimated COAs individual time step 95 percent credible interval; 4) dataframe containing values parameter latent parameter chain iterations. can used plot posterior distributions credible interval around estimated COA.

title: Fits a test-tag integrated Bayesian Spatial Point Process model to estimate individual centers of activity from acoustic telemetry data using Stan — COA_TagInt
text: nind Number tagged individuals nrec Number receivers ntime Number time steps ntest Number test tags ntrans Number expected transmissions per tag per time interval y Array detection data, row = individual, column = receiver, matrix = time step test Array test tag detection data, row = individual tag, column = receiver, matrix = time step recX Receiver coordinates east-west direction (projected scaled computational efficiency) recY Receiver coordinates north-south direction (projected scaled computational efficiency) xlim East-west boundaries spatial extent (receiver array + buffer) ylim North-south boundaries spatial extent (receiver array + buffer) testX Test tag coordinates east-west direction (projected scaled computational efficiency) testY Test tag coordinates north-south direction (projected scaled computational efficiency) ... Additional arguments passed sampling rstan. can include setting chains, iter, warmup, control. Please see rstan::sampling info.

title: Fits a test-tag integrated Bayesian Spatial Point Process model to estimate individual centers of activity from acoustic telemetry data using Stan — COA_TagInt
text: COA_TagInt_Bayes returns object class stanfit returned rstan::sampling. See 'rstan' package documentation details. function returns list containing following components: 1) summary detection function parameters; 2) time required model fitting; 3) time-varying detection probabilites receiver; 4) estimated COAs individual time step 95 percent credible interval; 5) dataframe containing values parameter latent parameter chain iterations. can used plot posterior distributions credible interval around estimated COA.
